Hears this sort of... Once, the Buddha was in the country of Varanasi, in the gathering of the wise and the birds flying.
At that time, there was an elder of the four castes in the country, named Yue Nan, who was extremely wealthy, with abundant rare treasures, cattle, horses, fields, and houses.
Nan was stingy and jealous by nature, did not believe in morality, and did not enjoy giving.
Before sunset, he always ordered the gatekeeper not to let any beggars in.
Nan had a son named Candana, who was also stingy.
After Nan's life ended, he was reborn in that country as the son of a blind beggar woman.
Her husband said:
You have a serious illness and are now pregnant. I am poor and have nothing to clothe and feed you, so you should leave.
The wife left the house as instructed, and not far away she found a large pile of dung, where she stayed.
In the ninth month, she gave birth to a son, but the child was also blind. The mother would go out begging for food to raise him.
When the child reached the age of seven, the mother said:
I have raised you for a long time. Now you can go out with your cane, take your begging bowl, and beg for food. You should say with pity:
'In the world, the poor suffer the most.
Now I, with meager blessings, was born into a poor family, and my two eyes are also blind and cannot see. Moreover, I am despised by others.
If someone now gives me a little food and drink to relieve my hunger, it would be like rain from heaven, quenching the thirst of the thirsty.'
The child, hearing his mother's words, went out to beg from house to house. He also went to the house of Candana.
When the child just arrived, the gatekeeper had just gone out for a short while. The blind child went straight in and stood in the courtyard, speaking as his mother had taught him.
At that time, Candana was on the high observation tower. Hearing his words, he became greatly enraged. He called the gatekeeper and asked:
Who let this blind beggar in?

The gatekeeper was greatly frightened and immediately pulled the blind child down outside the gate, injuring his head and face, breaking his right arm, destroying his food container, scattering his rice on the ground, and causing great pain to his body.
The child cried out in grief. His mother heard it and immediately ran to the child, saying:
What kind of scoundrel is molesting my child?
My child is still young and both eyes are blind. What offense did he commit to be treated like this?
What did He Yi do to offend Heaven?
The child replied to his mother:
When I reached this gate to beg, there was a loud-voiced person who called out to a strong man to pull me down and injure me. My body is in great pain like this. I will die soon.
At that time, there was a guardian spirit above the gate who said to him:
The pain you have obtained is still slight. The greater one is yet to come.
Because you had wealth in your past life but did not give it away, you have obtained hardship.
Wealth and nobility in the world are impermanent. If one is wealthy and noble but does not practice charity, it is as if one has no wealth.
After death, one will suffer even more pain, and then regret, but what benefit will that be?
